title: Composed of Primes Dividing
content:
**ComposedOfPrimesDividing m n:**

An integer m is composed of primes dividing n if every prime factor of m also divides n.

Example: 8 is composed of primes dividing 6, since 8 = 2³ and 2 | 6.
mathContext: This is the key predicate - we're looking for numbers whose prime factors are 'contained in' another number's factors.

title: Smooth Numbers
content:
**IsSmooth m n:**

m is 'smooth' with respect to n if primeFactors(m) ⊆ primeFactors(n).

Smooth numbers are central to many algorithms in computational number theory.
mathContext: The terminology 'smooth' comes from number-theoretic sieving algorithms.

title: The Function f(u)
content:
**f(u):**

The smallest v > u such that all prime factors of v divide u.

Equivalently: The largest v such that no m ∈ (u, v) is smooth w.r.t. u.

The definition uses Nat.find with a proof that u² always works.
mathContext: This is the central object of Erdős #459. It measures the 'gap' until the next smooth number.

title: Lower Bound: f(u) ≥ u + 2
content:
**f_lower_bound:**

For u ≥ 1, f(u) ≥ u + 2.

Reason: u + 1 always has a prime factor not dividing u (by Euclid-style argument).
mathContext: This is why f(u) ≠ u + 1 - consecutive integers share no common prime factors.

title: Upper Bound: f(u) ≤ u²
content:
**f_upper_bound:**

For u ≥ 2, f(u) ≤ u².

Reason: u² has exactly the same prime factors as u, so it's always smooth w.r.t. u.
mathContext: This gives the trivial upper bound. The key question is when f(u) is much smaller.

title: Trivial Bounds
content:
**trivial_bounds:**

For u ≥ 2: u + 2 ≤ f(u) ≤ u².

This captures the basic range of f(u).

title: Prime Case: f(p) = p²
content:
**f_prime:**

When u = p is prime, f(p) = p².

Reason: The only numbers smooth w.r.t. prime p are powers of p: 1, p, p², p³, ...

The first power > p is p², so f(p) = p².
mathContext: Primes achieve the maximal bound! This is because primes have only one prime factor.

title: Even Number Bound
content:
**f_even_bound:**

When u is even, f(u) ≤ 2^k where 2^k is the smallest power of 2 > u.

Reason: Any power of 2 is smooth w.r.t. any even number (since 2 | u).
mathContext: Even numbers have good bounds because powers of 2 are always available.

title: Minimal Case: f(2^k - 2) = 2^k
content:
**f_minimal_case:**

f(2^k - 2) = 2^k = (2^k - 2) + 2 for k ≥ 2.

This achieves the minimal bound f(u) = u + 2!
mathContext: These are the examples where f(u) - u is minimized. The gap is just 2.

title: Almost-Sure Linear Growth
content:
**f_almost_all_linear:**

For almost all n (density 1), f(n) = (1 + o(1))n.

This means f(n)/n → 1 for a density-1 set of integers.
mathContext: Despite the irregular extreme cases, the 'typical' behavior is linear growth.

title: Irregular Growth Theorem
content:
**irregular_growth:**

Both extremes occur infinitely often:
- Infinitely many u with f(u) = u + 2 (minimal)
- Infinitely many u with f(u) = u² (maximal)

This is the key insight: f has no regular growth pattern.
mathContext: The function oscillates between its bounds infinitely often.

title: Example: f(2) = 4
content:
**f_2:**

f(2) = 4 = 2².

The only numbers smooth w.r.t. 2 are powers of 2. The first > 2 is 4.

title: Example: f(6) = 8
content:
**f_6:**

f(6) = 8.

6 = 2·3, so smooth numbers are products of 2s and 3s: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, 12, ...

The first > 6 is 8 = 2³.

title: Erdős Problem #459: SOLVED
content:
**erdos_459_solved:**

Combines all the main results:
1. Trivial bounds: u + 2 ≤ f(u) ≤ u²
2. f(p) = p² for primes
3. Infinitely many minimal (u+2) cases
4. Infinitely many maximal (u²) cases

Cambie's observations settle the main questions about f(u).
mathContext: The problem asked to 'estimate f(u)' - these results provide a complete characterization.
